questions.question: What is a pattern in the casting process? (LO1)

answers.c: A model used to create a mould cavity

explanations.a: A pattern is a replica of the final casting, designed to form the cavity in which molten metal is poured. It accounts for various allowances like shrinkage, machining, and draft.

questions.question: Why are patterns made larger than the actual casting? (LO3)

answers.b: To compensate for shrinkage and machining allowances
answers.d: To avoid the use of cores

explanations.a: When molten metal cools and solidifies, it shrinks, which could lead to dimensional inaccuracies. To counteract this, patterns are made larger by adding shrinkage and machining allowances.

questions.question: What is the function of a runner in the moulding process? (LO1)

answers.c: To distribute molten metal to the mould cavity

explanations.a: A runner is a passage in the gating system that directs molten metal from the sprue to different sections of the mould cavity, ensuring smooth metal flow and reducing defects.

questions.question: Why is draft allowance provided in a pattern? (LO3)

answers.a: To prevent the pattern from breaking
answers.b: To make removal of the pattern from the mould easier

explanations.a: Draft allowance ensures that the pattern can be easily withdrawn from the mould without damaging the cavity walls. It prevents sand particles from sticking to the pattern.
